intro: Synodon calyptratus, commonly known as the Cape sugarbush, is a small evergreen shrub native to South Africa. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its dense, compact growth habit and leathery, elliptical leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in terminal panicles, which are followed by small, round, fleshy berries. It is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, exhibiting drought tolerance and a slow growth rate. Synodon calyptratus is often used in rock gardens and as a decorative plant due to its attractive foliage and hardy nature.
